configuration.title: greenpatterns - Baltimore Open Land Data
configuration.author: Bnia-Jfi

children.children: This mapping project was partially funded through an agreement with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. Forest Service, Northern Research Station. The Northern Research Station of the U.S. Forest Service seeks to improve people’s lives and help sustain the natural resources in the Northeast and Midwest through leading-edge science and effective information delivery. For more information, visit the Urban Waters Partnership site.
The City of Baltimore has more than 18,000 vacant lots that could be converted into uses that enhance neighborhoods and promote resiliency and sustainability.

In order to help neighborhood stakeholders identify greening strategies for these vacant lots, the City developed the Green Pattern Book that provides guidance on ways to achieve its vision of integrated green amenities.

There are 8 patterns within the Green Pattern Book. Mapping sites that show characteristics of the eight patterns is an essential tool for coordinating efforts and collectively achieving the vision defined by neighborhoods. In 2013, the Baltimore Neighborhood Indicators Alliance (BNIA-JFI) piloted a publicly- accessible, interactive map for this purpose using the pattern community-managed open space. Now, in 2014, BNIA-JFI is enhancing the map features and adding a second element for stormwater management. Future iterations of the map will include components of the remaining six green patterns.

Understanding how these sites impact urban waters and the communities that surrounds them requires ongoing information about the social, economic, and environmental characteristics of the City and the region. BNIA-JFI is leveraging existing socioeconomic data from the Vital Signs report and integrating it with data related to sites with potential to reduce runoff and nutrient loads to the City’s watersheds.

For each element of the Green Pattern Book, BNIA-JFI compiles data from a variety of primary sources and adds it to a spatial database that connects to Vital Signs community-based indicators, real property records, vacants to values properties, and adopt-a-lots. It is made accessible via a web-based interactive map.

Urban and suburban areas, including many of America’s post-industrial cities, grapple with how to manage abandoned and vacant properties When these properties are deconstructed or demolished, vacant lots lie in their wake. The Green Pattern Book, developed out of a grant from the US Foreast Service’s Northern Research Station to Baltimore City, is a tool to assist urban residents, administration, and community and nongovernmental organizations in "greening" these vacant lands and improving quality of life in the city. The book presents eight green project types for vacant lots, depending upon circumstances including community preferences, land tenure, and available funding, and provides extensive design guidelines around site selection, site layout and implementation, permits and zoning, maintenance, and funding. The Green Pattern Book is a robust tool for planning and implementing community greening initiatives throughout Baltimore, and is relevant to many other cities in America and beyond that are wrestling with problems stemming from vacant and abandoned properties. The Green Registry extends the relevance and impact of the Green Pattern Book, by providing a central repository for mapping past, current, and potential greening efforts. Most greening efforts are community-inspired, organized, and driven. We hope you will be inspired to think about a greening effort in your neighborhood, and that you use the Green Pattern Book and Green Registry as tools in your effort to help Baltimore achieve a greener future!

dictionaries.alias: Public Art per 1,000 Residents
dictionaries.layerdescription: The number of works of public art per 1,000 residents. These works include, but are not exclusive to, murals, monuments, sculptures, mosaics, and stained glass. The Baltimore Office of Promotion and the Arts tracks works created through the 1% for Public Art and Baltimore Mural Programs and maintains general inventories of public art and murals. Additional inventories of public art exist, but not at a comprehensive citywide scale and hence cannot be broken down into cross-neighborhood analyses.

dictionaries.alias: Median Household Income
dictionaries.layerdescription: The median household income is the middle value of the incomes earned in the prior year iby households within an area. Income and earnings are inflation-adjusted for the last year of the 5-year period. The median value is used as opposed to the average so that both extremely high and extremely low prices do not distort the total amount of income earned by households in an area.

dictionaries.alias: Percent of Children Living Below the Poverty Line
dictionaries.layerdescription: This indicator measures the percentage of persons under the age of 18 living in households where the total income fell below the poverty threshold out of all children in households in an area. Federal and state governments use such estimates to allocate funds to local communities. Local communities use these estimates to identify the number of individuals or families eligible for various programs.

dictionaries.alias: Percentage of 3rd Grade Students who met or exceeded PARCC Reading
dictionaries.layerdescription: The percentages of students who met or exceeded PARCC exams in reading and mathematics in 3rd, 5th, and 8th grades. Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers (PARCC) scores measure the number of students scoring in one of three classifications out of all students enrolled in that grade. Students can either be rated as exceeded, met, approached, partially met, or did not meet expectations of a subject. This indicator includes only those students who have tested as exceeded or met expectations.

dictionaries.alias: Percent of Students Switching Schools within School Year
dictionaries.layerdescription: The percentage of 1st through 12th graders who change schools out of all students in a school year. Students must have attended both schools for which they were registered for at least one day. Additionally, this indicator only identifies the share of students that change schools for any reasons and not the frequency, number of school switches, or change in residences in a school year. The percentage reflects the last home address available for the student who changed schools. This may or may not be the home address provided for the first school that they are registered to attend.

dictionaries.layerdescription: The percentage of 12th graders in a school year that successfully completed high school out of all 12th graders within an area. dictionaries.alias: High School Dropout/Withdrawal Rate
dictionaries.layerdescription: The percentage of 9th through 12th graders who withdraw from public school out of all high school students in a school year. Withdraw codes are used as a proxy for dropping out of school based upon the expectation that withdrawn students are no longer receiving educational services. A dropout is defined as a student who, for any reason other than death, leaves school before graduation or the completion of a Maryland-approved education program and is not known to enroll in another school or State-approved program during a current school year.

dictionaries.alias: Liquor Outlet density (per 1,000 Residents)
dictionaries.subgroup: Children and Family Health and Well Being
dictionaries.layerdescription: This indicator reflects the number of business establishments that possess a Class A (Off Sale package goods no on-premises consumption - 6 days, 6:00 a.m.- Midnight. No Sunday sales except Sundays between Thanksgiving Day and New Year's Day upon issuance of a special license for each Sunday) or BD7 (tavern) business license that allows them to sell beer, wine, or liquor. Other liquor licenses to restaurants or on-premise consumption were not included in this analysis. This number is provided by 1,000 residents to allow for comparison across neighborhoods.

dictionaries.alias: Average Healthy Food Availability Index
dictionaries.subgroup: Children and Family Health and Well Being
dictionaries.layerdescription: The Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future (CLF) calculated HFAI scores for all food stores in Baltimore, in summer 2012, using an adapted version of the NEMS-S (Nutrition Environment Measures Survey in Stores) tool. The NEMS-S tool was developed by researchers at the Rollins School of Public Health at Emory University to measure the nutritional environment of food retail stores and was designed to assess healthy food availability in grocery and convenience stores. CLF obtained a food permit list from the Baltimore City Health Department in August 2011, which includes all sites that sell food, such as stores, restaurants, and temporary locations such as farmers.

dictionaries.alias: Median Number of Days on the Market
dictionaries.layerdescription: The median number of days that homes listed for sale sits on the public market in a given area. This time period is from the date it is listed for sale till the day the contract of sale is signed. Private (non-listed) home sale transactions are not included in this indicator. The median days on market is used as opposed to the average so that both extremely high and extremely low days on the market do not distort the length of time for which homes are listed on the market.

dictionaries.alias: Median Price of Homes Sold
dictionaries.layerdescription: The median home sales price is the middle value of the prices for which homes are sold (both market and private transactions) within a calendar year. The median value is used as opposed to the average so that both extremely high and extremely low prices do not distort the prices for which homes are sold. This measure does not take into account the assessed value of a property.
